item.title: Wireless Internet Access For Farms
item.description:
While living and working on a farm has its perks, getting reliable broadband internet can be a challenge. Conventional options like DSL and Cable might not be feasible due to distance limitations, often leaving farms outside their service areas. Don’t worry, there are other solutions for obtaining reasonably priced internet access in rural areas. These alternatives focus on services that overcome distance barriers or eliminate the need for physical cables...

item.title: Bosign is broadening its range of technology products
item.description:
Bosign, a privately held Swedish company known for designing, patenting, and producing reasonably priced, top-notch Scandinavian lifestyle products, has introduced a new line of tech accessories for mobile device users. A standout feature of the new iPad Carrying Sleeve is its discreet leather fold-out handles, offering a convenient alternative for carrying the iPad. Measuring 28cm wide, 21cm high, and 1.2cm deep, the iPad Carrying Sleeve is crafted from felt to shield iPads from scratches and dust...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/bosign-is-broadening-its-range-of-technology-products/

item.title: Kickstarter spotlight: An innovative USB cable that charges smartphones at double the speed
item.description:
Minsoo and Emily Seo have developed a USB charging cable, DouBBleTime, that significantly reduces charging times for iPhones and Samsung Galaxy phones compared to standard cables. As explained on their Kickstarter page, typical USB cables attempt to communicate with the connected device while delivering limited power. In contrast, the DouBBleTime cable features a switch that prioritizes charging, effectively decreasing charging time. Source: Kickstarter. The Seos state on their Kickstarter page that a unique chip within the switch communicates with the connected computer, signaling that it only requires charging energy and not data syncing...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/kickstarter-spotlight-an-innovative-usb-cable-that-charges-smartphones-at-double-the-speed/

item.title: Business Internet Access Companies
item.description:
Consumers access the internet in various ways, and businesses have similar options, along with some exclusive ones. Let’s explore the choices available for companies at their business locations. Popular consumer broadband choices include DSL and cable for stationary setups, and 3G for mobile use. 4G wireless is emerging, with providers like CLEAR offering it for both fixed and mobile applications. In remote areas, satellite broadband delivers connectivity where wires can’t reach...

item.title: Houston, We’ve Got A 4G Solution
item.description:
Are you satisfied with your current internet service, or does it feel slow, unreliable, and overpriced? Many people struggle with limited broadband access. Residents of Houston, Texas, and surrounding areas like The Woodlands and Pasadena now have a new option: CLEAR, a 4G wireless broadband service. Powered by Sprint and Clearwire’s WiMAX technology, you can check their coverage map to see if you’re eligible. Houston isn’t the only location with access to this 4G wireless broadband service...

item.title: Business Broadband Options in Rural Areas
item.description:
By: John Shepler Businesses located in bustling city centers have a wide array of broadband Internet options, unlike their rural counterparts. While the lack of service providers in less populated areas might make it seem like broadband is a luxury they can’t afford, there are actually several options available, depending on the location. Rural businesses might feel limited in their connectivity choices. Unlike their city counterparts, they don’t have numerous service providers vying for their business...

item.title: Altec Lansing introduces durable mobile accessories at CES
item.description:
Altec Lansing is launching new lines of durable chargers, power banks, cables, and cases for smartphones and tablets. Expected to be available around the second quarter of 2016, these accessories will have rugged features like IP67-rated, military-grade construction for waterproof, dustproof, and shock-resistant functionality and device protection. The new products will include: Altec Lansing Everything Proof Power Packs (3,000, 6,000, and 10,000 mAh): These power banks are designed for smartphones, tablets, and MP3 players, offering up to 100 hours of talk time, 75 hours of music, 50 hours of video, or 4...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/altec-lansing-introduces-durable-mobile-accessories-at-ces/

item.title: Can Satellite Be The Answer to Your Business Broadband Needs?
item.description:
By: John Shepler Are you feeling stuck because your business needs internet, even if it’s just local? Have you considered cable and DSL but found them unavailable in your area? Don’t worry, there’s a solution for getting high-speed internet, even in remote locations. The answer is satellite internet! Forget about expensive cable or fiber optic lines; this video explains why looking up is the way to go: Here are 10 important things to know about satellite internet for your business:..

item.title: 20/20 Mbps Speed on Copper and Fiber
item.description:
By: John Shepler Business broadband needs have increased steadily, driven by the shift from text-based information to multimedia and the migration of business operations to cloud services. Simple, low-speed connections are no longer sufficient, with basic internet speeds now reaching tens of Mbps. A common choice for smaller businesses and remote workers is a 20/20 Mbps connection. This speed adequately supports individual users, small teams, or retail locations while remaining affordable...

item.title: Beogram 4002/4004: Replacement of a Broken Cable Clamp/PCB Holder
item.description:
During the restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5513), a broken cable clamp/PCB holder presented an opportunity to test a replacement part file. A fellow Beogram enthusiast from New Zealand shared the file, and in return, received access to parts in my Shapeways store. Photos document the broken clamp, the 3D-printed replacement, and the final installation. The new clamp fits securely with the PCB, keeping the audio cable properly positioned. With the successful trial complete, the part was made available for purchase in my store for other B&O enthusiasts...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/beogram-40024004-replacement-of-a-broken-cable-clamppcb-holder/

item.title: WiMAX 2 Will Challenge Fiber For Speed
item.description:
The idea that copper and wireless technologies are outdated in terms of bandwidth is circulating. While copper has found new life as a last-mile solution for Metro Ethernet services, and wireless stands out for its unmatched mobility, a new wireless technology is emerging that might surpass even fiber optic speeds. It’s surprising to think that wireless could outpace fiber in terms of bandwidth. While not all fiber optic services offer top speeds of 10 GigE, with many customers receiving 50 to 100 Mbps, especially in the case of Fiber To The Home (FTTH), the prospect of achieving 100 to 300 Mbps wirelessly anywhere in a city is enticing...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/wimax-2-will-challenge-fiber-for-speed/

item.title: Where Are T1 Lines Available?
item.description:
If you’re tired of unreliable DSL and cable internet for your business, consider a T1 line. While DSL and cable are suitable for home use, T1 offers a different level of service. As a regulated telecommunications service, T1 ensures consistent bandwidth and reliable uptime, unlike the consumer-grade alternatives. T1 lines are widely accessible for businesses and function similarly to utilities. If your business has electricity, water, and phone service, you can likely get a T1 line...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/where-are-t1-lines-available/

item.title: When Asymmetrical Bandwidth Works Just Fine
item.description:
Businesses have often dismissed asymmetrical bandwidth in favor of symmetrical options, sometimes leading to unnecessary expenses or frustratingly slow speeds. How do these symmetries work? Symmetrical bandwidth offers identical upload and download speeds, often labeled as 3 x 3 Mbps Ethernet or 100 x 100 Mbps Fast Ethernet. A classic example is the T1 line, with a fixed 1.5 Mbps for both uploading and downloading. T1, DS3, and SONET exemplify symmetrical bandwidth services, a legacy of their development by telephone companies for bulk voice calls, requiring equal bandwidth in both directions...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/when-asymmetrical-bandwidth-works-just-fine/

item.title: The Ultimate Wireless Firewall: Networks That Don’t Connect
item.description:
By: John Shepler Network security has become a crucial aspect for any business with an internet connection. Reports of security breaches are alarmingly frequent, and it’s possible that we’re only seeing the surface of the problem. While publicized breaches often involve compromised customer data, including sensitive information like credit card numbers, many businesses choose to remain silent about intrusions that don’t directly impact their customers to avoid negative publicity. Can Everyone Afford Cyber Security?..

item.title: Gigabit Internet Speed Is Easy to Find
item.description:
By: John Shepler Internet bandwidth needs have skyrocketed. While 10 Mbps was once considered high-speed, now even mid-sized offices need around 100 Mbps. For businesses dealing with video production, cloud applications, software delivery, or many users, Gigabit speeds are becoming essential, and thankfully, readily available. #1 Choice: Ethernet over Fiber Fiber optic internet is a future-proof solution. Its infrastructure can handle increasing bandwidth demands, from 1 Gbps to potentially 100 Gbps in the future...

item.title: 4G Wireless Expands Across The Nation
item.description:
If your home or business needs affordable broadband internet, there’s good news: a solution might be closer than you think. CLEAR, a company pioneering 4G Wireless broadband using the WiMAX standard, is expanding its reach to more cities. These include: Washington DC Metro Grand Rapids, Michigan St. Louis, Missouri Rochester, New York Syracuse, New York Eugene, Oregon Merced, Oregon Salt Lake City, Utah Richmond, Virginia Tri-Cities, Washington Visalia, Washington Yakima, Washington..

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacing the DIN 5 Cable with a Cable Featuring RCA Plugs
item.description:
I am rebuilding a Beogram 4002(5513) turntable to use with a McIntosh Preamplifier. The standard DIN5 connector on Bang & Olufsen equipment is incompatible, so I am replacing it with RCA connectors for the best shielding and lowest EMI. Direct installation inside the turntable offers superior performance compared to adapters. For optimal sound, I chose high-quality, open-ended RCA cables from Sounds Heavenly in the UK. These cables feature individually shielded, twisted-pair left and right channels, embodying an “audiophile” design...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/beogram-4002-5513-replacing-the-din-5-cable-with-a-cable-featuring-rca-plugs/

item.title: 3G 4G Mobile Bandwidth
item.description:
Mobile internet usage has increased, but bandwidth limitations are comparable to the early days of dial-up compared to today’s broadband. Let’s examine current mobile internet speeds. The current standard, 3G wireless, provides speeds between 500 Kbps and 1.5 Mbps through cellular carriers. These carriers are the same ones providing cell phone service, using the same towers, so coverage is identical. The demand for 3G increased dramatically after the iPhone’s release. The first iPhone utilized AT&T’s EDGE network, a 2...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/3g-4g-mobile-bandwidth/

item.title: Broadband Business Internet Service Options
item.description:
Almost every business today relies on the internet or will soon. Even small, independent businesses still using old-fashioned credit card machines will eventually adopt electronic verification, email, and basic websites. Meanwhile, businesses already comfortable online are looking to upgrade their bandwidth to handle cloud-based services. Let’s examine the different broadband options available. Business internet options can be broadly categorized into two types: shared and dedicated connections. Similar to residential services, shared connections divide bandwidth among multiple users, leading to lower costs...

item.title: Backing Up Broadband
item.description:
Over the past few decades, broadband internet has become essential for businesses, with speeds and data usage skyrocketing. This begs the question: what happens if your internet goes down? We’ve Quietly Become Dependent The shift to digital operations has been so gradual that many businesses don’t realize the impact of a complete internet outage. You understand the consequences of a power outage, but have you considered how to maintain operations if your internet connection fails?..

item.title: When Broadband is Hard to Find
item.description:
For businesses in bustling city centers, finding network and telecom services is usually not a problem. The challenge is finding the best deals on connectivity, trunk lines, and cloud services, as there might be lesser-known options available. However, for businesses in rural areas or home offices, options might seem limited and expensive. Surprisingly, there might be more bandwidth choices than you realize. Traditional Telecommunications Services Businesses with commercial addresses can typically access services like POTS phone service and T1 lines, using existing copper cable infrastructure...
